how_calculated: Tree canopy cover represents a 'top down' mapping perspective in which tree canopy over-hanging city features (such as sidewalks) is measured. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify COPD, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.

how_calculated: Number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only.

Counts were calculated as described above and summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
SourceDescription: Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System

how_calculated: The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September summed over a 5-year period for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department.
SourceDescription: New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates

how_calculated: Numbers are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the 5-year summed population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates, to produce average annualized rates. Quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. The average annual age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32.  Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.

Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning AND are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.
SourceDescription: American Community Survey (2013-2017 5-yr estimates)
